attachments.title: How do you obtain the transaction uuid after submitting an invoke transaction using the nodejs HFC
attachments.text: Im using the hyperledger HFC to send requests to the blockchain . How can I obtain the uuid of a transaction after submitting an invoke transaction using the sdk ?
attachments.fallback: How do you obtain the transaction uuid after submitting an invoke transaction using the nodejs HFC

text: done
<@U1JB7QCBD|ashnur> has joined the channel
<@U0S5KF44D>: thanks!

Hi, so I would like to deploy the simplest possible chaincode, like hello world or something and to test it. I was able to setup the devnet and I even ran the marbles demo locally, but that uses some old stuff. When I tried to use the new node-sdk, I started running into issues with npm install
<@U1JB7QCBD>:  What issues?

<@U0S5KF44D>: stuff like this  `Error: EPERM: operation not permitted, rename '/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/sdk/node/node_modules/grpc/node_modules/node-pre-gyp/node_modules/npmlog' -> '/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/sdk/node/node_modules/grpc/node_modules/node-pre-gyp/node_modules/.npmlog.DELETE'`

another one `npm ERR! enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, chmod '/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/sdk/node/node_modules/grpc/node_modules/node-pre-gyp/node_modules/mkdirp/bin/cmd.js'`
windows, mac, or other?
windows host, vagrant ubuntu box that is on github
from the devenv
I am on mac, but I thought the instructions for windows in the README.md addressed these issues.  Are you following all windows-specific instructions there?

so yeah, i am probably not following them because I haven't noticed them
<@U1JB7QCBD>: Have you tried running “make node-sdk” and/or “make node-sdk-unit-tests”?  If not, pls try to run.
on what machine should I do this?
from the vagrant box?
yes

i tried to run make node-sdk, it ran for some time then npm error: `npm ERR! enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, chmod '/local-dev/sdk/node/node_modules/grpc/node_modules/node-pre-gyp/node_modules/rc/node_modules/strip-json-comments/cli.js'`
Let me see if I can get some other windows folks to comment
duh, i forgot  … try “sudo make node-sdk”
or similarly, “sudo npm install hfc -g"
i am a javascript/node dev :smile: there is a HUGE stigma on using sudo npm install -g :slightly_smiling_face:
anyway, trying it

you have to use “-g” for any node module to install a binary, and “hfc” has a binary which can currently be used to drive tests thru the node sdk.  In the future, there will be other commands added to the hfc binary
sudo make node-sdk died again
I think I will put this vagrant box aside and try a clean one
ok, sounds like a good idea
if that doesn’t work, I’ll try to find another windows developer to help
I think the main issue is that I was using synced folders
so I will avoid those too.
<@U0S5KF44D>:  btw, actually, most people I know using npm and installing with -g are using nvm from <https://github.com/creationix/nvm>

text: with that you never need sudo for -g

however in this case, this might be the reason why things did not work out
so i am not going to use that either

<@U0S5KF44D>: so the main reason I am confused, is that it is not clear which part of the repo serves what purpose? so why do we have the node-sdk inside a repository that also has chaincode, and also lots of docs. Even though I see the continous work, I am not aware of the development practices that for example guarantee that whatever markdown file I am reading atm, it will correctly describe the state of the repository in that moment. Also, why do we still promote the old marbles demo, when the sdk in it is deprecated so to say? Normally I would have repositories separately for the hyperledger, the sdks, the chaincode related stuff and maybe even the documentation, but that also depends on what people are doing. 
Also, the more I read this thing the more it seems that this is basically an IBM internal project, almost everyone here on slack who is active seems to be IBM related persons
